_claude-sonnet-4__What management actions are available to aid forest recovery after a wildfire, and what is known about their effectiveness?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several management actions are available for forest recovery after a wildfire.
[Statement 2]: The effectiveness of management actions for forest recovery after wildfire varies and has been documented in scientific studies.
[Statement 3]: Thinning trees after a wildfire has been studied in five replicated, controlled studies across multiple countries.
[Statement 4]: Two studies in Spain found that thinning trees after a wildfire increased plant species richness.
[Statement 5]: One study in Canada found that thinning trees after a wildfire increased aspen sapling cover.
[Statement 6]: One study in the USA found that thinning trees after a wildfire decreased plant biomass.
[Statement 7]: One study in Israel found that thinning trees after a wildfire decreased the mortality of pine seedlings.
[Statement 8]: Post-fire salvage logging shows mixed results for forest recovery.
[Statement 9]: One study in Canada found that logging after a wildfire decreased the species richness and diversity of mosses.
[Statement 10]: Seeding interventions have shown limited effectiveness for forest recovery.
[Statement 11]: Three studies in the USA found that seeding herbaceous plants in burnt forest areas decreased the number and cover of native species.
[Statement 12]: The same three studies in the USA also found that seeding herbaceous plants in burnt forest areas decreased tree seedling density.
[Statement 13]: Those three studies found that herbaceous plant seeding had no effect on total plant cover or species richness.
[Statement 14]: Sowing tree seeds specifically has shown more promise for forest recovery than other seeding interventions.
[Statement 15]: One study in Brazil found that sowing tree seeds increased the density and species richness of new trees.
[Statement 16]: Using prescribed fire as a post-planting management tool for forest recovery has shown mixed results.
[Statement 17]: Two studies found that prescribed fire after replanting trees increased the survival and sprouting rate of those planted trees.
[Statement 18]: One study found that prescribed fire after replanting decreased the size of the planted trees.
[Statement 19]: One study found that prescribed fire after replanting had no effect on the size and survival rate of planted trees.
[Statement 20]: Debris management is another post-fire management action.
[Statement 21]: One study in Spain found that removing burned trees and branches after a wildfire did not increase European wild rabbit numbers compared to removing only the burned trees and leaving branches in place.
[Statement 22]: Natural regeneration of forests following a disturbance can show time-dependent effects.
[Statement 23]: One study in Canada found that natural forest regeneration increased moose numbers relative to more intensive management in the short- to medium-term.
[Statement 24]: The same Canadian study found that natural forest regeneration did not increase moose numbers relative to more intensive management in the longer term.
[Statement 25]: For logged forest areas, reseeding has shown limited benefits.
[Statement 26]: One study in the USA found that reseeded logged areas had similar reptile species richness, diversity, and abundance compared to areas left to regenerate naturally.
[Statement 27]: The same US study found that reptile communities in reseeded areas were not more similar to mature forest stands than those in areas left to regenerate naturally.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How does the effectiveness of community-based forest management vary across different countries according to the available evidence?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The effectiveness of community-based forest management varies significantly across different countries.
[Statement 2]: In Ethiopia and Nepal, forest cover increased more in community-managed forests than in forests not managed by local communities.
[Statement 3]: In Colombia, deforestation rates in community-managed forests did not differ from deforestation rates in forests that were not managed by local communities.
[Statement 4]: In Colombia, deforestation rates in community-managed forests did not differ from deforestation rates in uninhabited national parks.
[Statement 5]: Additional evidence from other countries shows mixed results for community-based conservation approaches.
[Statement 6]: In Pakistan, involving local communities with park management was associated with an increasing population of Himalayan brown bears.
[Statement 7]: In Brazil, areas where community-based management of fishing practices was implemented had a higher abundance of river turtles than areas with no community-based management.
[Statement 8]: In the Philippines, fewer crocodiles were killed after rural community members were paid a small incentive to protect Philippine crocodile sanctuaries and an education and awareness campaign was conducted.
[Statement 9]: In Mozambique, no killing of adult turtles was recorded during a community-based turtle monitoring project.
[Statement 10]: In Mozambique, fewer sea turtle eggs were lost to poaching during a community-based turtle monitoring project than before the project began.
[Statement 11]: Regarding monetary incentives for forest management, results also vary by country.
[Statement 12]: In Belize, numbers of black howler monkeys increased by 138% over 13 years after local communities received monetary benefits alongside other interventions.
[Statement 13]: In the Republic of Congo, most central chimpanzees reintroduced to an area where local communities received monetary benefits and other interventions survived over five years.
[Statement 14]: In Rwanda, Uganda, and the Democratic Republic of Congo, numbers of mountain gorillas declined by 28% over 41 years despite the implementation of development projects in nearby communities alongside other interventions.
